Award.AwardTitle: II-New: Enabling Analysis of Time-Dependent 3D Transparent Flows via Light Field Imaging and Displays

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports construction of a novel computational imaging system for efficient and robust acquisition and reconstruction of multi-scale flows. Since transparent flows do not have their own images but borrow appearance from nearby objects, the solution developed here directly acquires light paths off/through the flow wavefront/volume and then infers the physical properties of the flow. The acquisition system is portable and non-intrusive, to support on-site acquisition of various types of flows. Time-dependent 3D transparent flows such as fluid wavefronts, gas-liquid interfacial flows, and turbulent flows are ubiquitous in chemical, biological and environmental engineering. Accurate reconstruction of such flows under experimental setups have a broader impact on these areas and their applications, e.g., studying coal combustors and predicting natural phenomena such as warm rain and hurricane.

The new 3D flow acquisition system leverages emerging light field (LF) cameras and displays. An LF collects all rays emitting from a 3D scene. The research team explores two unique properties of LFs, ray sampling and multi-view imaging. A reconfigurable LF camera-display system is first developed to directly capture how the flow changes the light paths. Tailored computer vision algorithms are then developed to infer physical properties of the flow (density, velocity, vorticity, etc). Compared with state-of-the-art solutions, the new acquisition system is portable and can be re-configured to acquire various flow types ranging from completely specular wavefronts to transparent gas volumes and to turbulent flows laden with solid particles. For validation, direct (with all scales resolved) simulations of turbulent channel flows are conducted, without and with solid particles, against the experimental measurements using a mesoscopic approach known as the lattice Boltzmann (LB) method.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Time-dependent 3D transparent flows such as fluid wavefronts, gas-liquid interfacial flows, and turbulent flows are ubiquitous in engineering, biological and environmental applications. Accurate reconstruction of such flows under experimental setups, however, remains challenging. The challenges are multi-folded. Unlike opaque flows, transparent flows do not have their own images: they borrow appearance from nearby objects. Therefore, traditional 3D reconstruction techniques based on shading or texture analysis are not directly applicable. Moreover, many 3D flows exhibit an uneven and time varying density field, which adds additional difficulty to reliable reconstruction. Finally, the acquisition system needs to be portable and non-intrusive to support on-site acquisition.

During the course of this project, we investigated new computational imaging techniques by leveraging emerging light field (LF) cameras and displays for transparent flow acquisition and analysis. An LF collects all rays emitting from a 3D scene. In this project, we have explored two unique properties of LFs, ray sampling and multi-view imaging. We have constructed a reconfigurable LF camera-display system that aims to directly capture ray paths through the flow volume. We have developed tailored computer vision algorithms to estimate light paths for inferring the physical properties of the flow (density, velocity, vorticity, etc). We have further conducted simulations to verify the accuracy of the acquired 3D flows. We manage to simulate directly (with all scales resolved) turbulent channel flows without and with solid particles using two mesoscopic approaches known as the lattice Boltzmann (LB) method and discrete unified gas kinetic scheme (DUGKS). We mainly consider how the particle size and volume fraction affect the resulting turbulent flow and particle distributions. 

This research has resulted in publications that appeared at top tier computer vision conferences (IEEE CVPR) and computational fluid dynamics / multiphase flow physics journals (J. Comp. Phys., Computers and Fluids, Parallel Computing, Acta Mechanica). Representative topics of these publications include using light field imaging for conducting reliable volumetric flow acquisition, using multi-view capture systems for modeling and analyzing dynamic 3D shapes (including human), mesoscopic methods for turbulent particle-laden flows, and results of two-way interactions between turbulence and moving solid particles. 

In terms of broader impacts, two Ph.D. students in mechanical engineering have been partially supported, one graduated and a second is close to graduation, plus several others in computer science and engineering.  The research activities also contributed to an international conference held in summer 2018 at the University of Delaware: the 15th International Conference on Mesoscopic Method in Engineering and Science.
